description: Lagos served as a major center for Yoruba indigo dyeing traditions. Women artisans developed sophisticated resist-dyeing techniques including adire eleko (starch resist) and adire oniko (tied resist). The city's coastal location facilitated trade networks.
colonial_impact: Introduction of imported European dyes in 1880s began to compete with traditional indigo production. However, local demand remained strong through this period.
sources: British Museum Collection 1892.5.14; Colonial Office Records CO 147/89

description: Gbagyi women practiced traditional strip weaving techniques, creating narrow bands of cloth that were sewn together. Distinctive geometric patterns identified different family lineages.
colonial_impact: Minimal European contact during this period. Traditional practices continued largely unchanged.
sources: Missionary Records, Rhodes House Library MS.Afr.s.1840

description: Edo women created elaborate coral bead embroidery for royal court regalia. These textiles held significant cultural and political meaning within the Kingdom of Benin.
colonial_impact: The British invasion of 1897 devastated traditional craft production. Many artisans were displaced and materials were looted.
sources: British Museum Benin Collection; Smithsonian NMAFA 2005-6-1

description: Akwete weaving, practiced by Igbo women, produced colorful woven textiles with complex geometric patterns. The vertical loom technique was distinctive to this region.
colonial_impact: Early colonial period saw continued strong demand for traditional textiles. Local markets remained robust.
sources: Colonial Trade Reports, National Archives UK

description: Kano's famous dyeing pits produced indigo-dyed textiles traded across the Sahara. While men operated the dye pits, women were integral to preparatory work and pattern creation.
colonial_impact: Introduction of synthetic dyes in late 1890s began to alter production methods, though traditional techniques persisted.
sources: Colonial Office CO 446/7; Historical photographs, Birmingham Museum

description: Ibadan became a significant center for adire production in the early 20th century. Women artisans developed new designs and adapted techniques to meet changing markets.
colonial_impact: Colonial economy created new demand from European administrators and missionaries. However, imported textiles increasingly competed for market share.
sources: Field Museum Collections; Oral histories collected by University of Ibadan

description: Nsukka women combined textile production with pottery, creating ceremonial cloths used in traditional religious practices. These textiles held deep spiritual significance.
colonial_impact: Christian missionary activity from 1900s discouraged traditional religious practices, reducing demand for ceremonial textiles.
sources: Missionary Records, Presbyterian Historical Society; Nsukka Cultural Center archives

description: Iseyin specialized in aso oke production, where narrow strips were woven and sewn together to create prestigious garments. Women prepared thread and managed dyeing processes.
colonial_impact: Demand remained steady through colonial period for ceremonial occasions. Some adaptation to new color preferences influenced by European contact.
sources: Oral histories; British Museum textile collection

description: Efik women created intricate embroidered textiles for masquerade costumes and ceremonial dress. Coastal location influenced incorporation of traded materials.
colonial_impact: British colonial administration from 1885 disrupted traditional governance structures that supported craft production. Imported machine-made embroidery competed with handwork.
sources: Colonial photographs, National Archives UK; Calabar Museum records

description: The town of Akwete gave its name to a distinctive weaving tradition practiced exclusively by women. Complex patterns and bright colors characterized these prestigious textiles.
colonial_impact: Despite colonial disruption elsewhere, Akwete weaving remained economically viable throughout the colonial period due to strong local and regional demand.
sources: Anthropological surveys, 1930s; University of Nigeria, Nsukka archives

description: Various ethnic groups on the Jos Plateau combined basketry with textile production. Women created functional and decorative items integrating both traditions.
colonial_impact: Tin mining operations from 1900s brought economic changes and population shifts, but craft traditions adapted to serve both local and migrant communities.
sources: Mining company records; Jos Museum ethnographic collection

description: Alago women practiced traditional cotton cloth weaving, producing everyday textiles for local consumption. Techniques passed through matrilineal lines.
colonial_impact: Introduction of imported cotton textiles from 1890s undercut local production. By 1930s, traditional weaving significantly diminished as economic activity.
sources: Colonial trade statistics; Anthropological field notes, 1920s
